fullProgramDescription: The Environmental Systems major is an interdisciplinary program that focuses on the natural sciences, social sciences, and humanities to understand the complex interactions within the environment and between human societies and the environment. The Environmental Chemistry subplan emphasizes the chemical aspects of environmental systems, including the impact of human activities on the environment and the application of chemical principles to understand and mitigate environmental problems.
shortProgramDescription: The Environmental Systems (Environmental Chemistry) B.S. program provides a comprehensive education in the chemical aspects of environmental systems, preparing students for careers in research, industry, government, or further study.
classHighlights: The lower-division courses provide a foundation in chemistry, mathematics, and physics, including General Chemistry (CHEM6A-B-C), Calculus (MATH10A-B-C or MATH20A-B-C), and Physics (PHYS2A-B-C or PHYS1A-B-C).

Upper-division courses cover environmental chemistry, including Environmental Chemistry (CHEM151), Environmental Analysis (CHEM154), and additional electives in areas such as atmospheric chemistry and environmental engineering.

The program also includes coursework in Earth systems, ecology, and environmental policy, such as Introduction to Environmental Systems (ES1), Environmental Data Analysis (ES112), and Environmental Policy (ES155).
Students gain laboratory and field experience through courses like Environmental Chemistry Lab (CHEM154L) and Environmental Field Studies (ES193).
Additional electives allow students to explore specialized topics, such as climate change, sustainability, and environmental toxicology.
learningOutcomes: Apply chemical principles to understand and analyze environmental systems and problems.
Understand the impact of human activities on the environment and the role of chemistry in mitigating environmental issues.
Analyze and interpret environmental data using statistical and computational techniques.
Communicate complex environmental chemistry concepts effectively in written and oral forms.
Demonstrate an understanding of the interdisciplinary nature of environmental systems and the importance of integrating chemical, biological, and social factors.
additionalInformation: The program is administered by the Environmental Systems Program. Students are advised to consult with program advisors to plan their course sequence and ensure they meet all major requirements.
